fields.title: Love yourself
fields.content:
Love

There is so much more to life than finding someone who wants to be with you,

and there is so much more to it than feeling bad about someone who doesn't.

There is so much amazing time to spend finding yourself without hoping that someone will fall for you along the way - and it doesn't have to be hard or sad.

You need to fill yourself with love, not someone else.

Go on adventures, dress up for yourself, share your energy, smile a lot.

Do everything with love but don't romanticize life as if you couldn't cope without someone to be in love with.

Live for you and be happy in yourself. It is no less beautiful.



Friendship


Many friends will go behind your back.

You will fight for them and you will witness things that will change you forever.

You will lose best friends that you thought would be by your side forever.

You will realize that everyone has a past.

You will laugh, you will cry and sometimes you will embarrass yourself - but at some point you will realize that it doesn't matter.

At some point, you will sit back and realize that all difficult things only happen to people who can handle them. That this is who you are, and no one should ever try to change you; including yourself.

Life is wonderful, then it is hell, and then it is wonderful again. Between the wonderful and the hellish, it's ordinary and boring and routine.

Breathe in the wonderful, hold out through the hard and breathe out the ordinary.

Don't compare your chapter one to someone else's chapter fifteen.

Follow your own destiny and write your own story.



Listen



People will say things to cut you in half, but you have the power to not let their words turn into knives that cut you in half. But think about it; how many times have you lost your voice by saying things to someone who wasn't listening? Don't be that person.

One of the most respectful things you can give another human being is to listen.

When you talk, you only repeat things you already know, but when you listen, you often learn something new. One of the biggest communication mistakes is that we don't listen to understand; we listen to respond.



Learning


It's okay to feel confused. It is the beginning of learning something new. You shouldn't learn because you have to, but because knowledge is power. Knowledge is something that no one can ever take away from you. Learn because you want to know more. Learn because you are curious. Learn, because it makes you grow. And when you have learned, share it.

fields.title: Happiness
fields.content:
Positive Habits of Happy People

Extremely happy people have mastered these “happiness” habits to maintain their happiness every day and with consistent practice, so can you.

1. They Help Others

Happy people spend time helping others. This makes them feel good about themselves as they experience a “helper’s high” according to scientists.

2. They Buy Experiences

Happy people spend their money on experience, not just material things. While a new sofa will give you happiness for a month or so, a holiday trip with your family will create lasting memories.

 

3. They Slow Down And Appreciate Life

Happy people are busy, but they are not rushing around while they go about their day which can potentially leave them feeling stressed and unhappy.

 

4. They Make Sleep a Priority

Happy people make good sleep a priority. They know what it feels like to be sleep deprived and how it can impact them at a much deeper level.

 

5. They Exercise Regularly

Happy people know that exercise releases endorhpins and these “happiness hormones” make them feel better. They schedule regular exercise and keep active.

 

6. They Work On Their Relationships

It’s no secret that a happy relationship and a vibrant social life are components for being happy. Happy people know this, and they take the time to nurture their relationships—whether with their partners, friends, or family members.

 

7. They Set Goals And Have A Growth Mindset

Happy people have goals. They are always pursuing something meaningful—whether it is learning something new or raising children. These goals are intrinsic and personally significant to them. Happy people enjoy the process of achieving intrinsic goals because they resonate with their deeply held values and contribute to their personal growth, their health, and their relationships with others.

Learn more about happieness in this book "The happy mind" 

Buy "The happy mind"

fields.title: Valuation
fields.content:
Valuation is a kind of GPS on an unconscious level.

Some are inherited, some we have created ourselves.

It can vary over time.

When it chafes, we compromise our values. How is it for you? What are your most important values right now?

fields.title: Self esteem
fields.content:
To distinguish between the concepts of self-esteem and self-confidence -

where self-esteem is your feeling for and about yourself, your view and idea of who you are and the foundation and confidence you have in yourself that guides you to the right decisions and thoughts.

Self-esteem is also about the value you place on yourself. It is about the fact that you are valuable as a person and a human being no matter what you do and where you are in life.

As mentioned earlier, self-esteem is often confused with self-confidence.

They are related concepts and sometimes they are also linked.

Self-esteem is about you and your value as an individual in any situation. It is your view and the value you place on yourself. Self-confidence, on the other hand, can be influenced by situations where you perform well and feel good about yourself because of it.

For example, if you are a good cook, you have good self-confidence when it comes to cooking. You may have good self-confidence in one or more areas. You know that there are certain things you are good at and you also feel good and competent in these areas.

At the same time, you may have low self-confidence and not have found your belief in and feeling for who you are as a person. Then it becomes very important to be good in “your areas”.

You build your identity on what you do that you are good at.

If you ever fail in “your” area, that failure becomes very big and heavy to bear. Because you associate your identity with what you do, it means that the whole of you as a person is a failure - not just what you have done.  These situations are tough to get through.

You may also have good self-esteem. You feel confident about who you are as a person.

At the same time, you may have low self-confidence in one or more areas.

You know that you are not very good at playing tennis, for example, although you may do it a little now and then. But, that doesn't matter much because you don't link your value to what you do. You know that you are perfectly fine as you are, even though you are not very good at tennis. Not everyone can be good at everything, right!

You may also have both low self-esteem and low self-confidence. Then you think you are “worthless” both as a person and in what you do.

The root cause of this is low self-esteem, so that's what you need to work on and strengthen to begin with.

The best combination is of course both good self-esteem and good self-confidence.

It's important to understand that we often think that everyone else has much better self-esteem than we do.

A lot has been written about self-esteem in recent years and it has become a topic that is ok to discuss. Many people express their low self-esteem and sometimes it can be difficult to understand as an outsider when that image does not match the image of those around them - especially people who seem very happy and successful.

These are good examples of people with good self-confidence (good at what they do) but poor self-esteem (who am I really?).

It is perfectly normal for self-esteem to vary. Even if your self-esteem is basically good, you may periodically feel tired and doubtful about yourself. As soon as you feel better or things start to fall into place in your life again, your self-esteem will soon return to the same level.

However, we often tend to think that a normal level of self-esteem is much higher than it actually is. We like to compare ourselves to people who have very high self-esteem and think that this is the norm for what is normal.

If you do that, it's no wonder you think your self-esteem is low. In fact, it may be at the same level as most people's. Good self-esteem is a perishable commodity. It needs to be maintained and practiced to stay at a good level
